Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Matthias> Out of curiosity, will existing HUSH held on exchanges be automatically swapped for new HUSH? Do you have an idea how that will be managed?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <ComputerGenie - ChickenPool> the exchanges own them, so it's up to them what they do
but responsible exchanges should

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <RunningMantheCoin> @Matthias all exchanges hold Hush in t1 addresses. So yes, your Hush will be swapped when the new chain is launched

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <ComputerGenie - ChickenPool> that they will be swapped is less of an issue as if the exchanges will keep them or not üòõ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Matthias we work with every exchange that supports Hush and help them transition, as well as mining pools. Some need more help than others, some want to charge us, some just want to get trading back on so they get their fees

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Cryptopia and TradeSatoshi and Safe.Trade all plan to transition to the new HUSH, currently. Nothing written in blood, but we have contacts at all 3 exchanges and we are actively talking with them and they want to move forward. Nobody is talking about delisting us, partially because it's in their interest to collect fees from restarting trading

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> also, we are talking to various other smaller exchanges that are interested to add us or that we want to get on

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> additionally, many KMD mining pools will pick up HUSH, since it's super easy for them

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> that will lead to a whole new pool of HUSH miners (from KMD miners seeing a new coin on their pool), new HUSH hodlers (some miners will want to hodl for dat moon) and new liquidity-providers (miners who want to sell at current prices to pay their expenses)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and obviously some Hush pools that never had any use will probably drop support for us

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> all in all, it's very good for our ecosystem

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Matthias exchanges will swap balances and convert your t1... addresses to the new R... addresses of Hush v3

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> The old p2p network is not being shut down, Hush v3 uses new p2p + RPC ports. So in a sense, once block 500,000 happens and we transition, the "old" Hush chain becomes unsupported and disconnected from financial value (but all your privacy of your memo data is intact and can continue to be used), you could call the "legacy" Hush v2 a "Hush Classic" if you wanted, but it's more like an old version of our code that we don't use anymore

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> If I am not mistaken, 144.5 algorithm which produces ZER, which is not subject to ASIC mining

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <ComputerGenie - ChickenPool> `not subject to ASIC mining`
as defined by the idea that only 4 ASICs exist and no one will make one with variables

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> ASIC is not able to do anything except how to mine in the indicated algorithm))

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> @duke Is the change time for BTCH close?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <ComputerGenie - ChickenPool> that's true; however, changing the k&n values doesn't actually change the algo mining requirements of the ASIC
it does, in some cases, require more RAM than most onchip boards have and would require a slight modification to cgminer

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <ComputerGenie - ChickenPool> the only thing that "saves" those chains from ASICs is that manufactures can't be assed to play 'hide and go find' for specific coins and RAM increases the retail price

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> It seemed to me 144.5 more friendly for the GPU

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <ComputerGenie - ChickenPool> `more friendly for the GPU`
more friendly for the *modern* GPU; iirc, that's the one that pretty much killed all GPUs older than ~3-4 years

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <ComputerGenie - ChickenPool> older GPUs have the same or less RAM than ASICs, so if you hit a set of values that dumps ASIC due to RAM, then you also dump all those GPUs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Takoy_Nahal> By the way, there is a very effective response from ASIC to manufacturers in the form of a large number of algorithms, each coin creates its own, which makes it very difficult to monopolize the market with ASICs

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <ComputerGenie - ChickenPool> the flip of that is ROI; who's going to spend $4k on an ASIC that only has $3k ROI in 2 years because only 1 random coin picked those numbers?
